posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14516173
>Mostly safe because every town/canton/county/free city/dukedom was armed to the teeth and internal disputes were solved by the emperor as a neutral judge
Nope. The Emperor was rarely ever a neutral judge, considering it was his own political interest at stake. Henry the Lion was destroyed in years of active war against other powerful princes after he was abandoned to his fate by Barbarossa. Warfare was endemic in Northern Germany, even more so than in France. Parts of Southern Germany were able to avoid the endemic small war because of how the dukes of Bavaria and Austria ruled being far more centralized than say Saxony but they were frequently splitting hairs with other Princes.
>entirely based on ancestral customs and not written on the spot by some arrogant pseudointellectual
The law of the entirety of Germany (and the Empire as a whole) from the 12th century onwards was based on an ever updated version of Justinian's Laws and the Emperor or King could enforce these laws wherever he so desired even in the 15th century. Let alone earlier.
>>14516206
>Most people were tied to the land under feudalism.
Technically. Both of the largest non feudal regions of Europe existed under the HRE, the Low Counties and Northern Italy. To be extended to parts of Northern Germany.
>>14516518
>Just a fancy title.
The King of the Romans, and the Emperor were not meaningless titles. Until the start of the 13th century Germany as a Kingdom was the most centralized and powerful one in all of Europe and intermittently throughout the 13th the Emperor was more able than the King of France in resources. If you envisage the Empire to only exist in the 17th century, you would still be wrong but at least closer to it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14516173
This. It was a great place to live for the time, comparable to the modern EU which many people don't realise was partially modelled on it.

>>14516206
You're confusing British/late French style feudalism with HRE. Many guilds allowed you travel to practice your trades elsewhere. There are countless records of court scholars without noble rank moving around to sell their trades etc.

Feudel contracts themselves were very varied, but they were contracts you were free to leave if you wanted to love in a free city etc. (which the Emperor liked becaused it meant more taxes for him). It was also possible, for example, for a vassal to even successfully sue and keep the land if he could prove the lord did not keep his end of the contract (usually including defending, and in some cases feeding, clothing etc.).

Late medieval serfs in France and Britain were treated like absolute shit though, this is due to an entrenchment of the nobility which was less flexible than the HRE where you could chop off the head of your Lord's enemies one day and be promoted to knighthood for it the next (i.e. literally how the Habsburgers gained their first ever title).

>They were always elected. I wouldn't call that centralised.
Being elected does not make it decentralized. And for the Ottonian and Salian dynasties, it's just outright a lie. Only during the Great Interregnum was there a lack of a dynasty which passed the throne from father to son and after the period was over the Empire was hardly comparable to what became before it.

Slavery in the US was a brutal and inhumane institution that caused immense suffering for millions of enslaved blacks. Black people were treated as property and were denied their basic human rights. They were forced to work without pay and were subjected to brutal violence and abuse.

>but muh life quality!

One of the most egregious horrors of slavery was the separation of families. Black people were frequently sold away from their loved ones, resulting in permanent and heartbreaking separation. Children were often taken from their parents and sold to other plantations, never to see their families again. This practice was used to exert control over enslaved people, and to break their spirits.

Blacks were also subjected to brutal physical abuse. They were whipped, beaten, and raped. They were forced to work in dangerous and unhealthy conditions, with little rest or food. Many enslaved people were forced to work in the fields, where they were exposed to the hot sun and disease. They were also forced to do dangerous and grueling work, such as building levees or working in mines.

African-Americans were denied basic rights and freedoms. They were not allowed to marry without permission, and they were not allowed to own property or to vote. They were not allowed to educate themselves, and they were not allowed to worship as they chose. They were not allowed to leave the plantation without permission, and they were punished if they tried to run away.

Slavery had a profound and lasting impact on enslaved people and their descendants. The legacy of slavery continues to affect marginalized communities today through systemic racism and inequality. It is important to acknowledge the atrocities of slavery, to remember the millions of enslaved people who suffered, and to work towards a more just and equitable society.

posts.sub: Does the high crime rate of South Africa vindicate Apartheid?
posts.com:
The common justification of the National Party for keeping blacks segregated from whites, was that to allow blacks to live freely among whites (as well as East Asians who were generally treated as whites, especially in later years) was far too dangerous and that really it's just better for everyone if blacks are kept segregated.

At the time these kinds of arguments were dismissed as simply racist and totally unfounded by most people internationally, and yet it seems that post-Apartheid South Africa has seen such a huge increase in violent crime, particularly crime aimed at whites, that it seems the National Party was probably correct in their estimations.

While it's hard to argue that the Apartheid regime wasn't fundamentally racist, it's also undeniable that the National Party's policies kept crime far more under control than the current ANC government does, and that their policies were far more effective than anything implemented in post-Apartheid South Africa.

While I don't disagree that Apartheid was undoubtedly a racist policy, equally I think the huge crime rate of post-Apartheid South Africa has vindicated the policy of Apartheid in as much as it as proved that the National Party's fears weren't just based simply on racial hatred, but on a very real fear that has become a reality in post-Apartheid South Africa.

However, it seems in reality the argument that Apartheid was justifiable on some level because of the high crime rate in South Africa now gets pretty short shrift from most people.

Most people take the view that it's far better to live in a dangerous society that is free than a safe society that is oppressive, and I guess the question of whether post-Apartheid South Africa is a success comes down to that really.

Despite not being set in Europe, I reckon Warband does a wonderful simulation of medieval warfare. Not on a tactical level, but on a strategic one.
>when you marshal an army, you never know how many lords will show up, and when they do, or how long they stick around
>you don't know where your enemies are and how many troops your enemies have before they are near you
>because you don't know where the enemy is moving, and messages take time to travel, you might learn that enemy is besieging your capital, and you are unable to rescue it before it falls
>because the size of your retinue is limited, you have to rely on other lords, and you can't just go on a total conquest because the lords will abandon your campaign after a while

Compare this to Tranny Kings 3, where:
>you are omniscient (you know the exact number of troops and gold of every ruler)
>you are omnipresent (you can teleport anywhere, your armies can teleport too)
>you know immediately when enemy approaches your holdings
>your field army can be any size
>you don't have to rely on anyone

posts.com:
>Inbreeding will make your kids deformed.
The deformities we are discussing now are primarily caused by deleterious recessive alleles, and such alleles have a 6.25% chance of being expressed in siblings, 4% in first cousins, and 2% in people of the same ethnicity.
And not to mention the fact that inbreeding actually purifies the gene pool and purges such deleterious alleles as well as bad genes, making your offspring more genetically fit for the environment.
To quote Glemin (2003), "it is well established that consanguineous mating can purge a part of the mutation load" and "nonrandom mating (meaning consanguineous mating) can purge deleterious mutations regardless of their dominance level."
And lastly, this argument is an utter shit argument because racemixing, where your offspring are guaranteed to become genetic nightmares that are not suited for any kinds of environments and weak to many kinds of diseases from physical to mental, retarded breeding, where your offspring are also guaranteed to be retarded but not 100%, and homosexuality, where STDs and abuse are rampant (same for racemixing too), are legal and encouraged..

>Physical remains of people of the Gravettian have revealed that they were tall and relatively slender people. posts.name: Anonymous

>>14511313

The lack of spare parts is a bigger issue than people often mention, especially in North Africa where tanks and trucks would be rolling on dirt roads and sand.

Another major factor was the constant change in tank design. The British, Soviet and American had very specific and standard versions of each part of the tank, while the german had hundreds of different version of each part, turret, gun, tracks, engine, scope etc. Most of the design interference came from Hitler himself and led to extreme difficulty in mass producing and with much more expensive costs.

>>14508987
Nobody has mentioned the most obvious reason: a lack of the proper resources in proper quantities. Resource substitutes had to be manufactured, which were both inferior to the actual resource and more taxing on their chemical components (which were also manufactured from other resources that were needed for other things).

Resources like coal were used in huge quantities to develop artificial fuels, which greatly dininished the overall supply of coal for other parts of the economy. This actually led to a narrowly averted humanitarian crisis in Germany and France, where peoples’ homes (which used coal for heating) were unable to source fuel for the upcoming winter. The lack of bauxite coal meant that electricity and steel manufacturing were greatly hampered. Much of Europe relied on German coal reserves as well as imports from overseas. People don’t realize just how much coal had to be used to create the artificial fuel.

Unlike petroleum and fuel, which Germany had some natural sources of, Germany was lacking some other resources entirely. Can’t recall which at the top of my head. For some of these respurces, there was no way to substitute them with artificial versions, and so either inferior resources were used in their place or, more concerningly, nothing was used at all. This led to the infanous transmission failures in all German engines, for example.

The Allies OTOH had direct access to the worlds resources in all its vastness and all its diversity. There was a lot of wiggle room in what they wanted to produce and how much of each thing they wanted.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The present sucks, so it's inevitable that people look to the past with rose-tinted glasses.

Beijing is perhaps correct to say that Hong Kong's past doesn't quite deserve to be remembered with unreserved nostalgia, but perhaps they might take some conform from the thought that it's hardly a Hong Kong-only phenomemon.

Sure, in their case, the past happens to coincide unfortunately with the British colonial oppression meme and this makes them resentful given their belief that Hong Kong people ought to be loyal to state and race (and we shouldn't dismiss as insincere and performative the expressions of dislike and hatred for Beijing on the part of Hong Kong people for both cultural and political reasons) BUT I wouldn't dismiss the possibility that the general alienating nature of modern life in general isn't exacerbating Hong Kong's blues.

For many Hong Kongers, the Old Hong Kong of cheongsam dresses, smoky restaurants, colonialism and triads can represent a time of greater economic certainty, social stability, and cultural continuity.

This modern sense of place and habits being eroded away is something Beijing has played its part in, but I have no doubt that had British rule continued, things would still have changed, and sadly in many of the same ways.

There were some aspects of the British administration thet were undoubtedly more liberal, certainly towards the end, and I have no doubt that a wistful nostalgia for these on the part of localists and the demands of pro-democracy activists for Beijing to keep its promises are sincere.

I just think that the political side to this is only just one part of it, after all as Beijing correctly points out, Colonial Hong Kong wasn't a democracy and yet there is still some nostalgia of feeling even for the pre-1970s society. It's a longing to recapture a moment in time, an imagined simplicity of being, and an aesthetic sense.

The answer is very simple. The future doesn't exist in reality. It's merely a concept used to describe an unpredictable state of being. Humans estimate about the future based on the current trajectory of information, and with perfect knowledge there is a great chance of correct estimation, yet the inability to determine specific random factors on a small scale often have huge ramifications for the outcome.
God's omniscience could easily work the same way- He has a working knowledge of all that Is, and this gives him an immensely powerful model for predicting the future, but as the future is not a thing which exists but a description of a state of being, it is not required to fulfill the criteria of omniscience.
"The Future" isn't real. It's just a way we describe the difference between reality and our predictive models after the fact.
Not christian btw lol

>>14515693
There are two approaches to solving the problem in the OP: compatibilist (deterministic) free will and libertarian free will.
Compatibilist free will tends to have more support among secular people, but it's also a common stance among, for example, Calvinists. For the religious, compatibilism solves the free will issue with a triomni god, but its downside is that it makes the problem of evil more difficult to tackle. This is why people sometimes call Calvin's god a monster.
Libertarian will is more common among religious people in general. The upside is that it allows you to apply the free will defense to the problem of evil, but the downside is that it's harder to justify libertarian free will in the presence of a triomni god.
There you go, that's why it's relevant. It's one of the two possible replies to the answer in OP and it has different consequences than the libertarian one.

For a long time, I really thought America would be the exception somehow, but now I realize Juan Linz was right, parliamentary systems are just better overall. In the entire developed world, the only two pure presidential regimes are the USA and South Korea, and I don't think it's controversial to say they're some of the unhappier parts of the Global North today.

From "The Perils of Presidentialism":
>Perhaps the most important consequences of the direct relationship that exists between a president and the electorate are the sense the president may have of being the only’ elected representative of the whole people and the accompanying risk that he will tend to conflate his supporters with ‘the people” as a whole. The plebiscitarian component implicit in the president’s authority’ is likely to make the obstacles and opposition he encounters seem particularly annoying. In his frustration he may be tempted to define his policies as reflections of the popular will and those of his opponents as the selfish designs of narrow interests. This identification of leader with people fosters a certain populism that may be a source of strength. It may’ also, however, bring on a refusal to acknowledge the limits of the mandate that even a majority to say nothing of a mere plurality—can claim as democratic justification for the enactment of its agenda. The doleful potential for displays of cold indifference, disrespect, or even downright hostility toward the opposition is not to be scanted.
